story:
I want to raise money for Macmillan as I have lost 3 amazing family members this past year, Declan, Derek and Clive, to three different types of cancer. During this time, Macmillan nurses helped care for them as well as supporting my family and I'd like to know I played a small part in helping other family's get the same support.

I can't bake and I'm not very imaginative but I know people would pay to see me give up my favourite and only hobby, drinking. Starting today 18th December until 18th Feb. I haven't consulted my friends about this as they'd convince me otherwise in about half a second but, if you don't love me at my sober you don't deserve me at my drunk X

I thought I'd do it now to make it more of a challenge as Christmas and New Year are all about the bevs. In fact, as I was half way through writing this, I received a Christmas present of a bottle of wine and some gin so it's definitely going to be a long 2 months. 😂

They say Christmas time is the time of giving, so even if you don't like me you don't have to give through my link, there are other links on the just giving page you can choose from and I'll never know. 

If you choose to donate, thank you very very much and have the best Christmas and New Year and have a bev for me, or 11 please, please. 

Boris, if you open the pubs, can you at least reduce the price of a glass of coke, please and thank you.

pageSummary: I am raising money because they've helped my Grandad Eugene.
story:
This is for my Grandad, Eugene Campbell who came to the UK in 1955 from Jamaica to work.

My grandfather has always been here for me with great words of wisdom and support. What many people are not aware of is that he’s been fighting cancer for 14 years; colon cancer, prostate, and now stomach cancer and he’s done this with dignity and strength in abundance.

Unfortunately, this battle is coming to an end and the professionals have advised there is nothing more they can do for my him.

They have advised he will have 4 months - if he’s lucky.

Knowing my Grandad is in pain and battling with the mental torture of knowing this chapter on earth is coming to an end, cuts me deeply and therefore I’ve decided I want to do something in his honour and raise money for a great cause that has supported him over the years.

On the 19/12/2020 I will do a weighted boot run from New Mills-Wolverhampton approximately 67miles from start to finish I will start approximately 16:00 and run throughout the night. 

Please may I request that my friends and family share this and contribute a small donation towards my goal so that the support will continue to drive Macmillan's amazing efforts and give them the ability to continue to help our loved ones in their time of need.

Thank you in advance from myself and the rest of the Campbell family.

Much love to you all, x

story:
Hi friends, 

Thank you for clicking on my page!

Throughout January I plan on running 57k to raise money for Macmillan cancer support in memory of my lovely mum. 

To some of you, 57k in a month might not seem like a lot, but considering I’ve spent the most part of 2020 sat in bed watching Loose Women with my mum, hiding from miss Rona indoors, or working from home, 57k is my Everest! 

My amazing mum  was diagnosed with an aggressive form of liver cancer last Christmas at just 57 years old. As her condition deteriorated over the past few months, amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, mum’s incredible Macmillan nurse, Jo, continued to visit her (and so many others) weekly. Jo made my mum, James and I laugh when we were on our knees emotionally and gave us kindness, compassion and unfaltering support. 

The work Macmillan do for families faced with a cancer diagnosis is so incredibly important and although running may not seem like much, it’s a small way for me to say thank you for making a truly heartbreaking situation just that little bit more bearable and for putting a smile on my mum’s face when nothing else would. 

If you can spare even a pound I would be immensely grateful. 

Thank you so much in advance for donating whatever you can spare and supporting an amazing charity!

pageSummaryWhy: BHF research helped to save my life
story:
Go The Distance .100 Km . For your health ;for the challenge ;for the cause.Becoming a BHF Champion and improving health and well being and welcoming 2021 with new healthy habits .Thank you so much to everyone that has signed up so far its been a fantastic effort .Please do join our strava group also https://www.strava.com/clubs/gothedistance100k .

I survived 5 cardiac arrests in just over a day in 2012. I didn’t know it but I had developed a condition called Ventricular Arrhythmia. It causes the heart to go into overdrive so that it can no longer function. Various people with CPR training helped me to survive the 3 events outside hospital and I was fitted with an internal defibrillator (ICD) and since have returned to full fitness.

The BH funds CPR training and research which develops brilliant life saving devices such as ICDs. I am one of an increasing number of people who survive such events. Much of this is down to the work of the BHF and partner organisations. Join with us in helping to reduce the terrible human cost of heart disease.

I am a regular runner and have been since my 50s. Now aged 70 I regularly run 200kms a month. To make this challenge more stretching therefore I will look to run 300kms in this period.

The pandemic is the biggest challenge we've faced in our 60 year history. And it's led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, we've never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into ground-breaking science and support for the people who need us most.

So I am running for two people - one who has been a beacon of hope and positivity, a friend who actually got me running one drunken evening as a dare. Who manages a smile and a joke while sitting in hospital for weeks. We love you D. 

As a side note, Conversation Lab has agreed to double anything I raise so please help me to hand my husband a big bill!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my fundraising page for Cancer Research UK.

Two years ago, I had my prostrate removed due to prostate cancer, so I am competing in the Outlaw Triathlon on 25 July 2021 in support of Cancer Research UK, and to encourage anyone with prostate cancer to be positive about their future. This will be my first full ironman distance triathlon, and will include a 3.8km swim, 180km bike ride, and 42.2km marathon run. I will be competing in the 70-74 age group, and aiming to complete the 226km in about 16 hours. I have already started my nine-month training programme, under the expert guidance of my coach, Sam Mountain.

Beginning with sprint triathlons seven years ago, and gradually going longer through Olympic distance and middle distance triathlons, I have managed to complete all 12 of my races so far.  I therefore have every intention of completing this race too, but I know that a lot can go wrong in long distance triathlons.  Anything from cramp, gastro-intestinal problems, or dehydration, to crashes or mechanical problems with the bike, could force me to pull out of the race.  And athletes are required to complete their swim, bike and run within predetermined cut-off times to avoid disqualification. Yet no matter how far I manage to complete, your generosity will still benefit Cancer Research UK.  I have already paid my own registration fee and accommodation costs, so, apart from Just Giving's small administration fees, 100% of all contributions will go to straight to Cancer Research UK. 

Thank you for your help in achieving my target of raising £2,000 for Cancer Research UK.

pageSummaryWhat: A 'Christmas Cocktail' list for Marie Curie
pageSummaryWhy: The last part of life is so precious & valuable
story:
Do you know that EVERY single evening Marie Curie treat their wonderful patients to a 'favorite tipple'.  Can you imagine the difference this can make to one single day! 

Every evening a member of the Marie Curie team walk around and ask each and every precious, terminally ill patient, "what is your favorite tipple tonight?"  No matter what a patient ask's for, they ensure they hand over a glass of loveliness to them and to a member of their family who is visiting and comforting them.  How utterly incredible is this.. If for any reason they do not have the ingredients at hand, they will source it and ensure the order is fulfilled.

Cancer and all other terminal diseases are still out there regardless of our year... Please buy your fav drink for £6.00 and help!

The corona virus has stopped their usual fundraising
activities but we cant let it stop the care. They need our support more than ever this Christmas to make sure Marie Curie can be there for people living with a terminal illness and their families.

It is not a trek across the Sahara Desert or a Jungle trek, its a cost of drink and it makes a difference to people who are suffering..

Love Jo x

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Tim's memorial JustGiving page.

Tim passed away peacefully on 3rd December 2020 in hospital.

Tim, a retired Police officer, husband and father, had been a lifelong supporter of the RNLI. Family legend has it that the famous heroine Grace Darling is a distant relative. He started back in the mid 1970's as a Lifeboat Man on the Sheerness Lifeboat. He continued to support as a member following his transfer from the island to Cliffe where he served as the village bobby.

Upon his move to Norfolk in the late 1990's he was once again able to take on a more active support role. Although no longer physically able to serve on a lifeboat, he spent time travelling around East Anglia performing Sea Checks on leisure vessles. this gave him immense satisfaction and as anyone knows, if you ever received a Christmas card from him and Josie you can guarantee that it will have been one in support of the RNLI. 

Tim's funeral is on Wednesday 23rd December 2020 and the family have requested that there are no flowers but donations be made to the RNLI Sheerness Division via this page.

story:
Merry Christmas one and all!!!

A few sea swimming elves have decided to give our good friend Juanita (the Inganess wreck) a sprinkle of festive cheer. We do hope that the seasonal addition of a Christmas tree makes you smile. If this has brought you some joy please feel free to donate to the RNLI, a great charity that does amazing work to keep people safe at sea.

* Please note that we are keeping a close eye on the situation to ensure minimal disruption to the natural environment and will remove the tree at the end of the festive period *




Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

pageSummary: Trailwalker 2021 because We need a ruddy good challenge
pageSummaryWhy: We need a ruddy good challenge
story:
I wanted to try this amazing challenge as I have spent the past 10 months recovering from a Coccygectomy operation (removal of the Coccyx....ouch). It’s been an incredibly long and painful recovery and I’m still not there yet, but I needed something to spur me on, something to look forward to, and something get stuck into. 

I will do my very best to complete this challenge and would drag myself across the line if I have to.100km in just 30 hours!! My wife Georgina has had to help me and put up with me throughout this past 10 months and she will be joining me on the walk along with our good friends Ant and Laura Forbes.

Starting in Queen Elizabeth Country Park we will be walking along the South Downs Way on route to Brighton. We'll be starting out on the morning of 25th September and will continually walk until we arrive at our destination on the afternoon of the 26th.

We will be training for the next 9 months to prepare our poor feet for this 62 mile trek, in the meantime we would really appreciate your sponsorship!

Our goal is to raise £1400, all of which will go straight to Oxfam GB who are supporting those in poverty, those without clean drinking water, those in need of life saving basics and communities facing starvation.

It will also go towards The Gurkha Welfare Trust who are taking care of Gurkha veterans, their widows and their wider communities to ensure that they can live comfortably in their home country after serving in the British Army.

We're doing this for good causes, for the adventure, for the free curry at the end and we're just hoping we don't kill each other in the process.

Wish us luck!
